revised_title: The Genesis of the Scientific Advisory Committee to Britain's War Cabinet, 1939-1940
tldr: This article examines the formation of the Scientific Advisory Committee to the War Cabinet during World War II. It explores how the Royal Society played a crucial role in advocating for scientists to be involved in government decision-making. The article highlights the efforts of key figures like Sir Henry Tizard and the Physical and Biological Secretaries of the Royal Society, A. C. G. Egerton and A. V. Hill, in pushing for better communication and collaboration between the government and the scientific community during a time of great national danger.
